Translator: Helena Bowen
Reviewer: Denise RQ

13.text: When I tell people what I do for a living

16.text: they often respond by saying things like,

19.text: "Bless your soul, that must be difficult,"

25.text:
"It's so nice to see someone
not working for the money."

32.text:
I attended the wounds of people
crucified to circumstance.

36.text: Carry hope and band-aids in my briefcase,

38.text: share my own scars for street cred.

40.text:
I work with kids who see
their probation officers

45.text:
They wear sagging pants
and their parents' mistakes.

48.text:
Introduce themselves
as accidents waiting to happen;

51.text:
they are a Hollyhood
casting director's wet dream.

54.text:
Tattooed with a temper, do-ragged D-boys,
Boyz n the Hood, mi vida loca.

61.text:
because they have been taught
they are voiceless.

64.text:
Marginalization is the chip
on their shoulder.

66.text:
It is so heavy they walk with a limp,
pass it off as swag.

70.text:
Their fingers, more familiar with pipes
than pencils, eyes smoked closed,

74.text:
paint their world view the color of devils
as they search for God,

80.text: or anyone else they can just look up to.

84.text:
Emilio wants to change, so he keeps
a lucky penny in his pants pocket

88.text:
along with the quarter I gave him
to call with whenever he is in need.

92.text: In the desperation of his 15-year-old eyes

94.text:
I see more potential than an idea
Rivera never manifested on a canvas.

100.text: Scribes pieces of his soul into windows

102.text:
not knowing his pain
is as transparent as the glass.

106.text:
Sprays a masked moniker
underneath street lamps

109.text:
so he always shines brighter
than the darkness of his insecurities.

112.text:
He left his self-esteem
next to a cigarette butt

115.text:
at the bottom of a bottle
bought by relatives

117.text: who see no problem feeding fires.

121.text:
but believes nobody is listening,
so he commits another crime.

124.text: He likes going to court, because there,

126.text:
at least he knows that someone
is paying attention to his sentences.

130.text:
I am his social worker
attempting to make sense of his syntax.

134.text:
He didn't fall through the cracks;
they swallowed him.

136.text: I have seen it happen in broad daylight.

138.text:
Sun turning the other cheek
cowering behind the clouds.

141.text:
Concrete quicksand
traps youth like Venus fly.

144.text:
Homies who claim to have backs,
front, offering no help,

147.text: and so many of our kids are sinking.

152.text:
but there is only one way
to go from where he is.

154.text: I show him his heartbeat is his compass.

156.text: We look at the scars on his psyche,

158.text:
I ask if he is ready to replace them
with dirt underneath his fingernails;

161.text:
he asks me how
he is supposed to escape the sand.

164.text:
I remind him he cannot ask 
for one to guide his footsteps

167.text:
if he is not willing
to move his feet first.

169.text:
I speak in cliches; talk of butterflies
and phoenixes, and of hip hop,

173.text:
and of so many ugly things
that have bloomed into beauty.

176.text:
I speak in truths; I tell him
I don't know if things will be OK.

179.text:
I show him statistics are stalking him
and prisons plan housewarming parties.

183.text:
I tell him the streets, they don't change,
but I know that people do.

187.text:
Hope is not a helium balloon
that's slipped from our fingertips;

190.text:
we do not have to watch
potential float away.

194.text:
I work with kids who learn
to spell stigma before their first names.

198.text:
But each one is an artist learning to draw
their own conclusions.

201.text:
Their pencils are heavy burdens
built without erasers on purpose,

205.text:
because sometimes the best thing
you can do is not go back.

209.text:
I am a social worker, and no,
I don't do it for the money.

213.text:
I do it simply because
I still believe in people,

216.text:
and I really hope that you, and you,
and you, and you, and you,

221.text: and all of you, still do too.
